description: From Middle English bugle, from Anglo-Norman and Old French bugle, from Latin buculus (“young bull; ox; steer”).

entries.meaning: A simple brass instrument consisting of a horn with no valves, playing only pitches in its harmonic series
examples: Hypernyms: musical instrument, wind instrument, brass instrument

entries.meaning: Anything shaped like a bugle, round or conical and having a bell on one end.
The sound of something that bugles.
A sort of wild ox; a buffalo.

verbs.description: bugle (third-person singular simple present bugles, present participle bugling, simple past and past participle bugled)

entries.meaning: To announce, sing, or cry in the manner of a musical bugle.

description: From Late Latin bugulus (“a woman's ornament”).

adjectives.description: bugle (comparative more bugle, superlative most bugle)

entries.meaning: A tubular glass or plastic bead sewn onto clothes as a decorative trim
examples: How well so ever I fancied my lectures against pride had conquered the vanity of my daughters; yet I still found them secretly attached to all their former finery: they still loved laces, ribbands, bugles and catgut  […]

description: From Middle English bugle (“bugleweed”), from Anglo-Norman and Old French bugle, from Medieval Latin bugilla, probably related to Late Latin bugillo.

entries.meaning: A plant in the family Lamiaceae grown as a ground cover Ajuga reptans, and other plants in the genus Ajuga.
examples: Synonyms: bugleweed, carpet bugle, ground pine, common bugle
